learning_outcomes.description: Understand the role of the oceans in global climate dynamics and processes.
Demonstrate an understanding of how the physical dynamics of the ocean drives the biology, and directly influences the distribution, abundance and movement of marine life
Describe ocean circulation and the physical-biological processes in the marine environment
Understand a broad range of approaches employed in measuring and sampling physical-biological processes in the marine environment
Work in groups to analyse large oceanographic datasets using a range of methods to answer marine research questions

assessments.task_description:
You will need to pick a region around Australia (North, East, South or West) and explore the oceanography of the region using the Ocean Data View and My Ocean Viewer software introduced in the workshops. Describe what is going on in the surface, intermediate and deep waters to the deep waters using figures and text. The report should be 1500 +/- 10%, not including figures. More information will be provided on blackboard and in lectures.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
1) Physical Oceanography Quiz: 17/03/2026 2:00 pm

2) Chemical and Biological Oceanography Quiz: 30/04/2026 9:00 am
assessments.task_description:
To assess your learning across the modules there will be two quizzes worth 15% each. The quiz will consist of multiple choice and short answer questions. Each module will build on the last one and the quiz will also test your ability to link the content of the different modules as you progress through the course.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person on paper. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be handed in at the end of the workshop time period.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Field Trip Plan and Risk assessment
assessments.task_description:
This will be a field trip plan of up to 1500+/-10% words, with figures and tables (not included in the word count). This should include a risk assessment and field trip plan, and a brief description of the main methods undertaken in the field. Field trip plans and risk assessments are part of any career that involves field work, and this is designed to help you prepare for your future career in marine/field science.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You will pick a project to analyse physical or biological data from the Australian Integrated Marine Observing System. The research projects will be outlined in the second half of the semester, and you will work in a group in the workshops to analyse the data and answer a research question. You will be allowed to use AI to help you develop code to analyse the data.

You will give a 15 minute group presentation of your research findings (worth 15% of your grade) where you will be questioned about your approach and findings and will be provided feedback on your project. You will then write up an individual report of up to 2000+/-10% words (worth 20%), with figures, tables and references (not included in the word count). The report should include an introduction of what is the question and background information from the literature, methods, results and discussion. The report should reference the literature, and references should be in a standard format.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students are allowed to use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks . To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their project in the presentation questions. The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged in the presentation and assessment.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 4(23 Feb - 22 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Physical Oceanography

Key principles underpinning physical oceanography discipline.
learning_activities.topic_description: Physical Oceanography Key principles underpinning physical oceanography discipline.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction - history of oceanography

Introduction to the course and a brief history of oceanography including Australian Aboriginal history.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction - history of oceanography Introduction to the course and a brief history of oceanography including Australian Aboriginal history.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 6(16 Mar - 05 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Chemical oceanography

This series of lectures looks at how the chemical properties of the ocean. How is the chemistry impacted by the physics and how will it impact the biological oceanography (e.g. plankton productivity)
learning_activities.topic_description: Chemical oceanography This series of lectures looks at how the chemical properties of the ocean. How is the chemistry impacted by the physics and how will it impact the biological oceanography (e.g. plankton productivity)

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 9(13 Apr - 03 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Biological Oceanography

Plankton and biological oceanography in the oceans, linking back to the physics and chemistry.
learning_activities.topic_description: Biological Oceanography Plankton and biological oceanography in the oceans, linking back to the physics and chemistry.

learning_activities.topic:
Field Trip to Moreton Bay Research Station (MBRS)

Hands on field work at Moreton Bay Research Station to learn how to plan a field trip and collect water and plankton samples.
learning_activities.topic_title: Field Trip to Moreton Bay Research Station (MBRS)
learning_activities.topic_description: Field Trip to Moreton Bay Research Station (MBRS) Hands on field work at Moreton Bay Research Station to learn how to plan a field trip and collect water and plankton samples.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 10 To Week 13(04 May - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Research projects

The last few weeks of the semester you will work in groups and undertake a short research project analysing data from the Integrated Marine Observing System. You will present your findings as a group and write up your research as a short report to be submitted as your final assessment.
learning_activities.topic_description: Research projects The last few weeks of the semester you will work in groups and undertake a short research project analysing data from the Integrated Marine Observing System. You will present your findings as a group and write up your research as a short report to be submitted as your final assessment.
